'''Little Arthur Duncan''' (February 5, 1934 – August 20, 2008) was an [[United States|American]] [[Chicago blues]] and [[electric blues]] harmonica player, singer, and songwriter. He was a member of the Backscratchers, and over his working lifetime associated with [[Earl Hooker]], Twist Turner, Illinois Slim and Rick Kreher.<ref name="Dead">[http://thedeadrockstarsclub.com/2008b.html Thedeadrockstarsclub.com] - accessed December 16, 2011</ref> 

==Life==
Duncan was born in [[Indianola, Mississippi]], [[United States]],<ref name="AMG"/> and initially learned to play the [[drum kit|drums]].<ref name="Hanson">{{cite book
| first= Karen
| last= Hanson
| year= 2007
| title= Today's Chicago Blues
| edition= 1st
| publisher= Lake Claremont Press
| location= Chicago
| page= 146
| isbn= 978-1-893121-19-5}}</ref> In 1950, aged 16, he moved to [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]], and made acquaintance with both [[Little Walter]], who helped Duncan to learn the rudiments of [[harmonica]] playing, and [[Jimmy Reed]]. He found work playing his harmonica by accompanying [[Earl Hooker]], [[John Brim]] and [[Floyd Jones]].<ref name="AMG"/><ref name="Hanson"/> Billed and henceforth commonly known as 'Little Arthur Duncan', he played primarily in and around Chicago, and built up a local reputation over the years. He appeared with his own band in the Backscratcher's Social Club, which he also owned.<ref name="AMG">{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p384166/biography|pure_url=yes}}|title=Little Arthur Duncan |author=Jason Ankeny |publisher=[[Allmusic]] |accessdate=December 16, 2011}}</ref> Duncan worked in [[construction]] during the 1960s and 1970s, so was restricted to playing and singing in the evenings.<ref name="Hanson"/>

In 1989, Duncan recorded the album ''Bad Reputation'', which was released on the Blues King [[record label]].<ref name="AMG"/><ref name="Hanson"/>  He later appeared on a [[compilation album]], ''Blues Across America: The Chicago Scene'', alongside [[Detroit Junior]].<ref name="AMG"/> In 1999, Duncan recorded for [[Delmark Records|Delmark]], who released ''Singin' with the Sun'' that year.<ref name="AMG"/> On the album he was accompanied by the guitar player [[Billy Flynn (musician)|Billy Flynn]].<ref>{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=singin-with-the-sun-r442504/credits|pure_url=yes}}|title=''Singin' with the Sun'' > Little Arthur Duncan > Credits |accessdate=December 16, 2011 |publisher=[[Allmusic]]}}</ref>  ''Live in Chicago'' followed  in 2000.<ref name="About"/>

His final recording was ''Live at Rosa's Blues Lounge'', which was a [[live album]] recorded in Chicago in August 2007. One [[music journalism|music journalist]] noted "...spirited, gritty performances of [[Jimmy Reed|Reed]]'s "Pretty Thing," [[Howlin' Wolf|Wolf's]] "No Place to Go," and two [[Willie Dixon|Dixon]] favorites ("Young Fashioned Ways" and "[[Little Red Rooster]]") leave no doubt that Duncan lives and breathes electric Chicago blues."<ref>{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=live-at-rosas-blues-lounge-r1272261/review|pure_url=yes}}|title=''Live at Rosa's Blues Lounge'' > Little Arthur Duncan > Review |accessdate=December 16, 2011|publisher=[[Allmusic]]}}</ref> However, a subsequent lengthy illness and hospitalization meant that Duncan could not build on his success.<ref name="About"/>

Duncan died in [[Northlake, Illinois]], in August 2008, from complications following brain surgery.  He was aged 74.<ref name="Dead"/>
